It was very crowded right after Christmas. There was a five hour wait for Hagrids ride. But everywhere we went the employees all seemed to be doing their best to make sure our visit went as smoothly as possible even among the huge crowds. Kudos to Universal!

The universal park is perplexing in that a huge part of it consists of a simulated New York City and San Francisco. Not much to do there. As a fan of Harry Potter I would have preferred an expanded and more in-depth Diagon and Knockturn Alley. Walking in to it the first time is glorious. However the more time spent there the more you realize how limited it is. Gringotts is the most elaborate aspect with a wonderful ride. Highly recommend. Many of the stores however are just storefronts. The dragon over Gringotts is cool when it breathes fire (not working on the second day). The train to Islands of Adventure is awesome. (Also was not working on second day -“routine maintenance “. ). So here’s my question... if the Wizarding World is the biggest draw by far, why isn’t it bigger? Early entrance consisted of almost all guests walking through the Universal Studios park, heading directly to Diagon Alley (long walk from the gates) past the simulated New York etc. In Wizarding World be prepared to spend tons of money. Programmed Wands are $40 and up. I saw many kids waving these wands at various programmed things (fountains, windows) that were difficult to activate. A few employees (not enough of them) showing kids how to wave wands correctly for the 10 second response. Try the ice cream parlor for butter beer ice cream and other eccentric flavors like chocolate chili. Leaky Cauldron is a must. Do the Gringotts ride first and hit the wand store ( both have very long lines as the day goes on). Also the train line gets very long. Ride the train back and forth in the morning to avoid the hour long line later. Outside of Diagon Alley the rides are old and outdated. Suess World is cool for really young kids. ET, Men in Black, the big Greek temple are tedious compared to the Gringotts ride. I hope the park makes improvements and adds more to Wizarding World Diagon Alley. It would be cool if there was a wizards show on the stage there with special effects, a spell battle etc instead of a weird, campy singer with three back up singers. Knockturn Alley has great ambiance (dark and spooky with a dark arts store) but is way too small. This entire area should be expanded with more elaborate elements. Given the hyper inflated prices in the Diagon Alley stores I think they could afford this. We went in January primarily to avoid the massive crowds in high attendance times and for cooler weather. 70 degrees F was perfect but was still crowded. I cannot imagine being there during high attendance times. The waste of time standing in lines would not be worth the expense. Here’s another question...universal park was only open from 8 AM to 7 PM in January. So at this expensive highly popular park, why couldn’t They have done maintenance on the train and the dragon during the many hours the park is closed overnight instead of during the day? On to Islands of Adventure where you will find Hogsmeade. Stunning visual of Hogwarts castle and the greatest ride ever invented (forbidden journey). Flying through the air around Hogwarts is amazing. I want this ride at my house. The flying parts of this ride are epic but the intermittent parts that go inside Hogwarts are weird- more rudimentary. The town of Hogsmeade is cool. The roof tops and buildings are a masterpiece. Three broomsticks is a must of course. Pretty good food and excellent decor. However just like Diagon Alley in the other park, the more time you spend there the smaller it becomes. Again many storefronts (not actual experiences) and the stores have exorbitant prices. It was congested in the streets and stores. Again I cannot imagine being there during high attendance times and in the summer heat. And again there’s a weird show on the small stage with actors who look like they’re about to succumb to heat exhaustion. How about a quidditch demonstration instead or another wand battle or potions class etc? The rest of Islands of Adventure is huge (long walks). And of course Hogsmeade is in the back of the park (like Diagon Alley in the other park) so if the train is not an option you will have to walk through the entirety of both parks to visit both Diagon Alley and Hogsmeade ( which is a brilliant profit-making manipulation - must buy multiple park pass etc). Walking to the exit of Islands park takes about 20 minutes without small children or stopping along the way. The cartoon land in Islands is a surreal version of he’ll especially in the heat. Very loud repetitive music, weird old vintage stuff. Only attractions are a nausea inducing roller coaster and spider man rides. God help you if you have to walk through both parks to get to Wizarding world. If you plan your day in advance and hit the busiest parts of Wizarding world it is more enjoyable. Also more than one day is better.

This was a new ride introduced late December 2019, the wait was 90 minutes but well worth it. This is a 2 person ride, one on the motorbike and another in the sidecar. There are no loops in this rider, however does not detract from the thrill of this ride. It is fast and entertaining and you will want to have another turn! Highly recommended for all. Please note there is a height limit.

We had a fabulous time at Universal Studios. But our favourite was the Harry Potter section.. From wands and magic to trains and moterbikes... this is an awesome way to spend a day (or more if you have the time!)

We are annual pass holders at Universal in Los Angeles and love going there but the park in Orlando is even better. The quality of rides, food options and staff are much better in Florida. Well with the trip to sunny Florida and spend your time here for a few days.

Had a great time here. Spent 3 days at the park and made the most of express tickets. It's a world of it's own, with fun rides, food carts, shops, restaurants and just an amazing happy atmosphere. We visited in January so not a very busy time, as local kids were at school. Wednesday and Thursday were the best days but got busier on Friday. We were able to do many rides twice, sometimes three times. Did not get a chance to do Volcano Bay but there was already so much to do at Universal and Islands of Adventure. Loved Citywalk for its great restaurants and so many food options. Even managed to get halal food (our dietary requirement) at some restaurants. Some of the favourite rides were Men In Black, Escape from Gringotts, Spiderman, Harry Potter and the Forbidden Journey, Skull Island, Revenge of the Mummy, Simpsons, Transformers and many more. Even braved the very fast Hagrid's Motorbike Adventure ride!

We had a limited amount of time to go visit so we focused on a 2 park ticket for Harry Potter. Loved it! We opted not to get the express pass as it would’ve cost us an extra $700. We got to the parks shortly after they opened and our wait time for the rides we wanted was minimal. The only thing we didn’t have time to do was look at the castle for the Forbidden Journey ride. But again we just wanted to view the castle not ride the ride this go around since our girls were only 8 & 9. We did enjoy, Escape from Gringotts, Flight of the Hippogriff, the Hogwarts Express, the Wand show at Ollivander's (one of my daughters was chosen!) we tried butter beer and the girls tried some spells with the interactive wands. I don’t think the interactive wands work that well. So my advice is to have a game plan of what are things you must do or see, get their early and hit up your main attractions immediately and skip the express pass!

I didn't actually visit here in April 2019 but that's the only year I had to choose from. I actually visited here in April 2015 for my High School Senior Trip. It was amazing!! I remembered coming here with my family back when I was like 12/13 years old and it didn't have half of what it has now, for example, the new Harry Potter World is friggin' awesome!

My 11 year old and I went last summer and the trip was great. We stayed at Adventura which was clean and an easy walk to parks but the rooms are quite small. I would strongly suggest you do a vip tour not the high dollar one which I did not do but the less expensive one was well worth the money even with the fact we did not ride all the rides chosen. If you have any motion sickness stay off the simpsons ride I was ill for the rest of the night even taking Dramamine before.

Everyone ran to diagon alley but we took our time and explored. So many great things to see. The Horror make up show was fantastic. Sang along with the blues brothers and had my picture taken with scooby doo. Then ate and drank in Springfield with the Simpson's. Rode MIB, shrek, minions and my person favorite...The Mummy. What a fantastic 2 days.
Perfect park for Harry Potter’s fans & Grinch’s. Also enjoy roller coasters. Family favorite kids and adults attractions.

I finally went on the Harry Potter ride 10 years after it opened. Went on Hagrid’s motorcycle ride. Very fun. Warning, if you are a very large and tall person, you will not fit on Hagrid’s ride. The person I was with had to step off. Disappointing.
One of my favorite days ever! Harry Potter World is the best thing going here. Need dual park passes to enjoy to the fullest.
Loved all of this place, was a once in a lifetime trip for us with 4 generations of our family and all of them thought this was great
Great place for rides, shopping, exhibits, etc.. We were there during a rare slow time and got to ride all rides with no waiting. Rode several twice. No rushing and really enjoyed the parks.

We have been coming to this park since our kids were teenagers and 11 years later we still come as a family along with our seven-year-old granddaughter. The most popular part of Universal is definitely the Harry Potter theme area. It gets busy fast so head there first if you are interested. I don’t have any interest in Harry Potter but it was still really cool to go into this area. We missed the entrance to this so pay attention to the map. When you enter, you are in a whole different world. You feel like you are actually in the books\movies. Make sure to try some butterbeer (we prefer frozen) and ride Harry Potter and the escape from Gringotts! If you’re a fan of The Simpsons, there are rides, restaurant, and a whole section dedicated to the show. The rip rocket is a fun roller coaster and you get to pick the music you want to listen to while on it. The Men in Black ride is another favorite and if you go in as a single rider instead of a group, you get on quicker and avoid the longer lines. If you are in a wheelchair, you can ride this. Universal studios has 3-D / 4-D attractions that I was able to go into with my wheelchair. They include the Despicable Me Minion Mayham, Shrek, and The Jimmy Fallon ride. There are other rides and shows that will help fill up your day also. We usually spend the shorter day at Universal and we will spend a longer day at Islands of adventure. There’s no way we could ever do both parks in a day with our whole family so we always get the 2 day 2 park pass. We always make sure to catch the Halloween horror make up show and The Animal Actors on location. Both are great for all ages and very entertaining. The animal show uses rescue animals and showcases their different talents! Some of them have even been in movies or TV shows. My husband is a big Blues Brothers fan and they have a cool little show with actors singing songs from the movie. The universal superstar parade is also worth checking out while characters from different movies and shows dance and sing. There are several different theme restaurants to check out. They are not cheap when it comes to their meals. However, they have a family meal deal and a refillable cup deal. The refillable cup deal is great and definitely saves money on drinks! You are allowed to bring in bottled water, sandwiches, bags of chips, etc. (full details on website). This is definitely a money saver.

Ok, so second visit to the park, first one was ten years earlier. There were plenty of updates, and the beauty of some of the rides were that we couldn't remember them fully so we were still surprised.  We really enjoyed Gringots, Transformers, Jimmy Fallon, The Mummy, but most of the Blues Brothers performances. That is to name our personal favourites, but it is all great.  We were lucky to be there through the Mardi Gras shows, which were spectacular.

We visited for a full day, mainly because our kids are really into Harry Potter and wanted to see the Wizarding World. You have to buy tickets for two of the parks in order to see both parts of it. This was a HUGE expense when that's really the only reason you are even visiting. I had hoped that the rest of the park would have some great things that our family would enjoy to help make up for what we paid, but unfortunately, that was not the case at all. The only thing we enjoyed was the Harry Potter portion, and even with that one of the rides the kids really wanted to go on was broken so they missed it. Had I realized we only part of the parks we would enjoy was the Wizarding World, for the cost we would have skipped Universal and just gone to Disney again instead.

The Universal Studios VIP experience is the only way to visit Universal Studios!! Our tour guide was Logan. Logan is knowledgeable, full of life, fun, informative and an absolute joy to be around!! We saw all of Islands of Adventure and rode all the rides with 0 wait time in 4 hours. Words cannot express how awesome this experience was!!

We visited 2nd week in January and it was a good time without long lines. We ranged in age from 63 - 68 and had a great time. Rides are so immersive and the park is well designed so not too much walking. Lots of places to sit if you need a break and take out areas for food and drink. The only thing my friends complained about was the jerky movement o many of the rides was hard on the back, even though none of us have chronic issues. I love the parks and prefer Universal to Disney.

I’ve been to Universal several times and love it. The Harry Potter areas are particularly wonderful, full of detail and awesome rides. This is the first time that I’ve gone since having a child. We really went for my 6 year old nephew, and I knew going into it that my 2 year old wouldn’t be able to ride most of the rides. But good God, he can’t go on the rides in Seuss Landing?! Why make an area of the park for children and then make the height requirements so ridiculous. I’m not one of those parents who isn’t worried about safety either. I’ve been on all of the rides and cannot fathom why they wouldn’t allow a child his age on the Cat in the Hat. He can’t even go to the Minion Mayhem show. It’s literally a movie theater that kind of vibrates when something funny happens on screen. Really?...the only conclusion that I can come up with is that they really, really don’t want children in the parks. Thankfully, Disney is not nearly as ridiculous.

We spent one day at Universal with our son and his family. We spent so much time walking and standing in line that we didn’t enjoy it much. Also I got sick after eating at one of the restaurants. I don’t think we will go back again.
Amazing place to visit and takes pictures everywhere. Super magic and fabulous park in Orlando......

Our family of four really liked Diagon Alley. The entire area seems right out of the books/movies, which is a great experience. We really liked Gringotts Bank and Knockturn Alley. A must do is to take the train between the two Harry Potter areas. We also really liked the Kong Ride. Hulk Coaster is a classic ! We'll be back !

Universal is still a great theme park. I have enjoyed the changes they have made over the years with replacing Jaws and Back to the Future, however I feel the new rides are becoming more of the same. 4D rides, with big screens. I hope they bring some new rides in the future.

We had a great couple of days here. Its great just to walk around here. Much slower pace than disney, the rides are excellent and the special effects are awesome. We watched the the light and projection show at the end of the evening was great.

We spent two fun filled days at these two parks over a busy holiday weekend. Here are some tips to help you for your future trip experience.  First things first. You need to decide what are the important stops and then plan your experience around that. For us it was visiting everything and anything to do with Harry Potter. We wanted to get here, check out the wands and robes on day one (so the kiddos could use them at the parks). But let’s not get ahead of ourselves just yet...we need to get you into the park first.  There are multiple ways to purchase your tickets either on their website, with a travel agent like me or through another website like AAA. Here is what I recommend, get your tickets anyway you like (through me is the best way) on your mobile app or paper. The will call area to pickup your actual tickets can be a bit confusing. Also in my observation during the time I was there, most confirmations numbers did not work on the machine and you had to wait in another line for a ticket specialist to help you. Yes, we were one of these special people. It took them about an hour to fix our tickets and it was very frustrating as time was ticking away.  Ticket Tip: Express ticket/passes are separate from your ticket price and need to be purchased in addition to the park admission price. This can be quite costly as there are different levels for purchase. The express passes save on the long line waits and in a way very worth it but your ticket price almost doubles. So you have to weigh out what works best for you. But recommendation is to purchase park to park ticket. That is the only way to ride The Hogsworth Express from Harry Potter to the Wizard World of Harry Potter. The train ride is super fast and it’s a great experience for little witches and wizards. You feel like your in London as you enter the Kings Cross station and all staff stays in character to round out the experience.  Few differences between Universal and Disney. Universal gives you these paper cards - not a fan as they are easy to loose. Disney gives you magic bands which you wear and if staying on property you can charge food, beverages and merchandise back to your room. We love our magic bands but are very used to this process.  Park hours. Universal opens and closes with shorter times to stay in the parks. Typical day is 9am to 8 pm with fewer options for early access. Disney has greater time lengths with parks opening on average 8 am and staying open until 10 pm. Disney has spectacular fireworks and light shows at night too. But both parks have extra park hours for those staying on property of an hour before.  Food and beverage options are vast and each section of the park offers a variety of food themed to that area. But some must try’s are: butter beer, cauldron cakes, fish & chips can be found in both Harry Potter areas; Holmer’s Big Donut in Simpson’s area; giant turkey legs can be found all over but we got ours in Jurassic Park area and so on... There are choices for everyone. A few good restaurant choices are Vivo, Italian; Mythos, Mediterranean; Bubba Gump Shrimp Factory in Citigroup Walk; Amatista Cookhouse in Loews Sapphire Falls Resort but wherever you choose to eat the food quality is amazing and so is the service. Tip: if you book a package of room and tickets then you can make dining reservations. Otherwise it’s first come for tables. Few options are on open table but every little bit helps!   Harry Potter tips: Wands can be purchased at Oliveranders and there are two lines. One brings you to an experience show where the choose one child to be a part of the show and they explain how the wand chooses it person. Then you enter the wand shop where wands guides assist with asking you questions to aid in picking the perfect wand for you! The other door just takes you into the shop. There are two styles of wands - one that interacts with areas of the parks where your little wizard can turn on a fountain to flush a toilet so a spell and flick of the wrist. The other do not interact and are a higher quality. Or you can just pick a wand from one of your favorite characters too. They come with a map to help you find the locations that are inactive too.  There are tons of shops to find chocolate frogs, ice cream, apparel, gifts, bags, etc. Ride attractions in these areas are a must do as they all are equally as awesome but you must ride the new Motorcycle Rollercoaster. So cool and that’s all I can tell you - no spoiler alerts here.  The rest of the parks are divided into various lands. But some cool rides for thrill seekers are the Hulk Rollercoaster, Hollywood Rollercoaster which you choose your own music and takes a video of your ride (that’s hilarious!), minions, fast and furious, skull island, transformers , Jimmy Kimball race around New York.  Few last tips: download the Universal Orlando App on your phone. Be sure to upload your tickets and everyone who is in your party. This is ideal if you lose your tickets and an easy way to retrieve them. Also you can check wait times for rides, directions throughout the park, food options and so much more!  Need help planning your trip? Reach out to Posh Travel Destinations and we can assist you with all of your planning needs from which ticket to purchase, where to stay on and off property and what are the must stop dining locations.   Bon voyage,  ~ Felicia, xoxo

Loved it. There is no better way to describe IT. All staff were amazing, friendly and knowledgeable.  **UNIVERSAL STUDIOS**  It's a shame you need to pay so much, just for one park - Young families would be better off in Universal Studios, it's more 3 or 4D shows and kiddo rides like Spiderman, Men in Black, Simpsons, Minions, Shrek and so on.  Spiderman was definitely a favorite so I'm not knocking it - VERY IMMERSIVE (so was the Mummy!)  DISAPPOINTED.. Once inside Universal Studios, I soon realised we'd chosen the wrong Park (I'm 27 and went with my 43 year old dad)  I got to see Spiderman outside his ride longside all of your marvel favorites though, thay was pretty cool! They came past everyone riding wicked motorbikes waving at the kids etc.. Yes you can meet them if you check out the map and times etc  ONLY BIG RIDE in U.S was the rocking roller coaster - Must say it was one of my favorites though!! YOU EVEN GET TO CHOOSE YOUR OWN SONG TO ROCK TO!!!  Must see... Harry Potter escape Gringots, Diagon Alley - good luck finding it) Fast and Furious, Spiderman, Return of the Mummy, Men in Black, Rocking Roller Coaster, Transformers and Dr Dooms Fear Fall!!!  **ISLAND OF ADVENTURE **  WATER RIDES.. YOU WILL GET SOAKED not just a little.. I walked round in wet trainers all afternoon! Would definitely take a towl or swimmers next time*****  I spent most of the day in this park, after I upgraded my ticket...  HAGRIDS Motorbike ride was my favorite by far. I couldn't believe it! You get to 60 miles per hour a few times over, see mystical creatures, visit the forest and much more!!! The rest of the Harry Potter rides were also incredible and very Immersive!! *****very long queues, quieter at lunch time, no fast track, but single riders will get you to the front slightly quicker*****  I just loved this park from King Kong to Jurassic to the Hull and everything else.  BE PREPAIRED... Wear comfy shoes and take change of clothes or wear swimmers for the water rides!! Maybe even a towel. I did 23k steps in total and couldn't walk afterwards - probably because of the wet trainers I was walking in all afternoon.  Most rides I queued for an average if 10 mins. Hagrids was about 2 hours!! Worth it though so DO NOT GET PUT OFF BY THE WAIT, IT IS MORE THAN WORTH IT.  I wanted to visit here since I was 10. 17 years later, was soooo worth the wait!!!!  If your not a rides person, you can get lost in the shops and restaurants or go on the rides in universal, 3d glasses and Immersive but not scary at all.

My wife and I visited Universal Studios in late January on a weekend we thought wouldn’t be busy. Unknown to us, the park moved the Rock the Universe event onto that same weekend. It was way busier than normal unfortunately. The people were also very rude in line sometimes. Otherwise, we had a great time! We rode Revenge of the Mummy a bunch of times since it was my favorite. Some other highlights were Shrek, Men in Black, and Gringotts. Some of the 4D motion rides tended to make me dizzy and queasy but that is just me. My wife was completely fine on those rides. Overall, we loved visiting and plan to come back again in the future!
Very cool park, the minions, Tranformers, fast and furious and Shrek are the best ones, must visit, also has the new area of harry potter’s world with a new ride is amazing too!Must go!

We were staying in one of the on-site hotels, so managed to get in early and see the amazing Wizarding world Harry Potter experience nice and early before the crowds. I certainly suggest this as a great way to do it, but as soon as the park opens "properly" we moved on to some of the older rides.  We really like the 3D experience rides... Shrek, Transformers, Kong and Fast+Furious are all worth a bit of time stood in line.

We had a wonderful day. Wednesday so only small queues and crowds. Red Rocket, Mummy Returns and Spider-Man are stars of the show. Get a 2-day 1 park ticket as you will want to go to Islands of Adventures too - else you will be disappointed.

I have not been to universal since the days of Kong earthquake and jaws. I was impressed with the parks changes. Wizarding World of Harry Potter ups the game on themed entertainment. The wand experience was great and the wizards and witches helping the young ones complete their spells were fantastic. Food was great. My son is 4 and I wasnt sure what he’d think of the rest of the park but he loved it. He went on woody woodpecker coaster 6 times. We went in Feb crowds were low and wait times were usually the time it takes to get through the queue. Mardi Gras parade and food were great. Glad they still had et, I loved that ride when I was a kid. If traveling with young ones make sure you check the heights before booking. My 4 y/o didn’t make it on some rides like MIB.

We took our kids(5,8) to Universal while we were on vacation and opted to spend a little more and get the VIP tour. It was an extra $189 added into the $160 ticket, it included breakfast and lunch.   When we arrived it was 9am and our tour started at 9:30a. We parked valet(included in price of VIP ticket) and asked where to go. There was a walk to a small cafe for breakfast, no one showed us how to get there or escorted us to the cafe. It was a little bit of a walk and some confusion on where to go but we found it! The girl that greeted us was very nice, showed us where our table was and sat us down with a couple of families. We were confused because there was open tables and she didn’t say “Hey! These guys will be on your tour with you also!” She just walked away lol. The breakfast was fine, nothing fantastic. Had all the basics..eggs, bacon, bagels, pastries etc. Our tour guide showed up and asked what we were excited to do today and if we had any preferences. We did say we wanted to do the Jurassic ride, but told us it was too cold for that. So, we couldn’t go on.  We started our tour right at 9:30a. Our guide was super nice! She took us right to our first ride and from there we didn’t stop for 7 hours. We did 12 rides total. It was a lot. I was hoping to go to a show or something to break up the rides but there was no break except for lunch(45min). By the time we were done I think everyone had an upset stomach because of all the rides and running around for 7 hours. My 5 year old was so tired and so wasn’t my 8yr old that they didn’t even want to stay for the Super Hero dinner we had planned, they just wanted to leave.  I do like that she got us in front of all the lines and we literally didn’t have to wait at all. But, in the future they should take a survey on what people expect out of the experience. Our group was not ride focused 100%, and our tour guide was. She had us running all over and everyone was just exhausted by the end. I think we would of all liked to have time to stop and take some pictures, try some butter beer etc.  Over all it was fun! And my oldest really enjoyed it. The tour guide answered every single question he had and was so kind to him. She never once got annoyed with him lol. We would def do it again!

A wonderful day in the park from beginning to end. Arrived just as the park opened and walked directly to the back to Harry Potter. The wait was not crazy and the ride was exciting. Recommended rides include Transformers, Race Through NYC, Revenge of the Mummy and ET. Parking costs $27 and it is a long walk from the garage to the parks. They do have moving sidewalks.

January was an excellent time to visit. With express passes, we got to enjoy the park with minimal lines. Rides were fun, especially the 3D. I don’t do roller coasters so I can’t comment on those. We got a multi-park ticket for Harry Potter and we were glad we did.

We did Universal studio and Adventure Park in one day! We got here at 8AM and were done both parks at 3:30 pm. We did visit in January which is low season, so it was not that crowded and we got through lines very quick. If you are looking for adventure and want o live your childhood memories and dreams THIS IS THE PLACE!
We had lots of fun. We enjoyed so much, and now we have memories that will be with us forever. An amazing place
I could go in almost all the toys there. It’s a wonderful park. All the toys are thematic from the line to the central toy. And this provides amazing experience.

Better waiting times than Disney, but we ended up getting Express ticket - that is, we paid double. In the end, it was good to save time, but probably pointless. Visit the top 5, wait the 1h for each, and then you're done. The rest is just all the same. Avoid minions, it's for children, rubbish. And go after you visit Disney, as the crowd, despite being horrible, won't bother as much since Disney is like a nightmare.
loved it here!!! rides so good variety for everyone but drinks and food expensive but just like all the parks i recommend fast past
Great rides especially Kong and Jurassic Park!!! Crowded but expected. Park well maintained and clean. Be prepared to walk!!!

We love all universal theme parks including the rides and entertainment. However we decided to pay extra to experience the Halloween fright night. Very disappointed. Queues very long to get into each fright experience building and then to many people inside. You can see the creatures jumping out at the people in front so no surprise when they do it to you. The costumes and scenes were professional. Not worth the money and due to time scale not sufficient time to see everything. I suggest they reduce number of ticket sales.
I would say its amazingggg ... i was on saturday night and there were few diferent concerts and it was soo nice to be there. Recomend to everyone once in a lifetime you should go here

We went at the end of January. The temps were chilly in the mornings and evenings, but very nice once the sun got up and going. Jeans and long sleeved shirts would probably be enough for most people but, if you’re cold natured, take a light jacket or sweater. Going early in the year avoids the crowds of Summer. I think the longest we waited for any ride was twenty minutes. For most of them, we walked all the way to the front of the ride without stopping.

1. Bring your own food and drinks. No issues getting through security and the stuff in the park (although tastes great!) costs a small fortune. Buy a re-fillable cup...can be used every day at Universal Parks for a daily fee. 2. Don’t buy souvenirs at the Parks. Go to your closest Walmart. They have souvenirs for Disney and Universal (authentic) but MUCH CHEAPER. $13 for lanyard at Universal, $5 at Walmart.... ! 3. Speaking of lanyards, buy one before you go to put your express passes in. Then you don’t have to worry about losing them or digging into your wallet, purse, bag every time you ride. 4. Go EARLY. Parks aren’t open as long as you might think, so get your moneys worth. 5. Don’t rent a stroller, go to Walmart and spend $20. Give it to someone when you’re finished. $18/day for 5 days adds up! 6. Lastly, but most important, if you can (they aren’t cheap) BUY AN EXPRESS PASS and do it the day you go to each park (many times it is cheaper than getting online). These are worth their weight in gold. The time you save waiting in line can range from 15 minutes to over and hour. Don’t bother with one for Volcano Bay, they have a virtual line up, so you can play while you wait. But a must for Universal and Island! Had much happier kids than when we went to Disney without one!! It’s a great place to visit, my three year old was a bit to small to really enjoy it, I would recommend age 8+. Fab rides and spectacular visuals everywhere. Highly recommended!

We spent 5 days exploring both parks and I really enjoyed Studios. Love the Hollywood and San Fran parts, lots of fun 4D rides and enjoyed The Simpsons section  Again, I deducted one star as I feel the daily parking rate of $26USD is a bit much, considering how much you already pay for admission
Harry Potter was amazing! It was absolute perfection! The rest of the parks are very fun as well. Everyone is friendly and it is clean
Universal studios is amazing. It’s a wonderful day out to spend with family making amazing memories. Loved it.

There is a lot to pack in here and recommend starting with the Harry Potter attraction first because you will want to spend a lot of time there. Stay at a Universal-related hotel for an hour early admission. BIG benefit! Be aware that many of the rides are immersive 3D rides with a lot of rocking and rolling. They do a good job of putting you in the scenes but after a while they can get a bit repetitive. A fun experience overall and a totally different vibe than Disney. Much more adult-centric here.

We stayed at the Lowes Hotel connected to Universal Studios. If you can do it, its best to stay in one of the connected hotels. They are close. We were able to take the water taxi or walk to the park in minutes with little or no lines. Universal was unbelievable. We walked 26 miles in three days. It was a blast for the whole family. We were there at Christmas time including Christmas Day so keep in mind it was crowded. With the early/easy pass we were able to get in early and avoid lines on our favorite rides or attractions. The Harry Potter areas were very popular with children and you adults. We also purchased the meal plan that worked out well except we didn't eat enough times and had some left over meals or snacks. The employees were incredibly nice every where we went. It wasn't the cheapest vacation but if you can do it once, your children will remember forever.

Universal Orlando was supposed to be an awesome place to have spent my vacation...until we legitimately got robbed by people we thought were security people. We get stopped by these three individuals acting as security and they forcefully took my hubby away thinking he stole items from one of the shop. I was so scared but I legit thought they were one of those people who were just doing their job (don’t even ask me why we didn’t stop to ask for ID as they were forcing themselves and surrounded my family to make it look like my hubby had stolen stuff, IT WAS SCARY!) So I waited for my hubby to come back as I didn’t know where they had taken him. He comes back shaken and then realizes they had stolen from him as he and others were asked to check their items in their bags with receipts. This is while those thieves took his other bags while he wasn’t looking. It wasn’t just him this happened to, others had it happen to them too at the same time. Long story short, my hubby was so traumatized by this and after getting his head straight, he called Universal security to which they said they can’t do anything about what happened because apparently what happened was like some kind of organized crime ring and it happened to unsuspecting people like us...tourists from another country. Like how the eff can this park let this happen and do nothing about it???? We spent good money to be at a park like this, and although the items are just items that can be replaced, what would’ve happened if those people including my hubby got hurt in the process??? What then???? He got scared and didn’t know what to do but do as he was asked by again those people acting like security people and this whole experience at the theme park left a very sour taste in our mouths. I just cannot believe Universal Orlando says they can’t do nothing about what happened!!! I’m not asking for anything or compensation but I wish the theme park can be more understanding of the situation this put us in. We had two more days in our pass but my hubby refuses to go because the whole experience of being robbed and thinking he was guilty of something he didn’t do, made him feel that the park is unsafe to be in, which is the case. I just hope no one else has this happen to them. And I really wish Universal Orlando would be more understanding of this situation and those this has affected. Oh and because we had the items paid for in cash, unless we had proof we bought items there is nothing they can do which I think is a load of BS. They make so much money and compensating those who got affected by any means would’ve been the least they can do to take some of the sour taste of this experience away. I want everyone to know, DO NOT PAY FOR ANYTHING WITH CASH! Because they won’t reimburse you for the items stolen (which again is understandable) but still. Being unsuspectingly be robbed is not a great feeling and I want everyone to know that if it can happen to us, it can happen to you! I should’ve listened to my gut when this happened because the way those three individuals acted it did seem they were gonna rob us but then we got fooled into thinking they were security and this happened because we were so scared.

Universal is fun and a little more laid back than the bigger mouse oriented parks (not that I don't enjoy them- i just find it a little stressful) which make you reserve stuff way in advance... my visits always allow for a little more flexablity and relaxation since i don't have to be running around on a schedule.

We love to visit Universal Studios. I had read many bad reviews lately about security but they checked our bags at all the entrances. Most all the employees were very nice and helpful. Most of the lines moved quickly and the laser light show was neat to see. There were a few complaints we had that the park needs to improve upon. First and foremost the park hours. As much as you pay to get in and they close the park at 6PM and 7PM??? WHAT! One night closed at 6PM for a private party. Why should all the people who paid full price have to leave early because of a private party. This should be AFTER HOURS! Weekend hours were 8PM. The park hours should be at the very least until 8PM every night. Secondly, all the restruants and food venders close an hour before closing. So on a night they close at 6 all the food vendors are shut down at 5. Again...poor planning on Universal's part. Food should be served up until at least closing time. Don't send your customers away hungry. Thirdly, I love that the parks open early and have fast passes for those who stay in the resorts but only one park is open early. Shouldn't it be both? So past those few things we were happy and had fun. The park was also very clean and maintaince on rides shut down were announced a head of time.
So much better then Disney. I didn't feel rushed all day. So much more laid back and enjoyable. Harry Potter is amazing.

Have been here a few times a really great park that you have to visit while in Orlando lots to do plenty of restaurant choices, have been to Halloween horror nights and had a fabulous time would recommended and I shall be returning from the uk in the near future

We took part in a team building event in the park, which gave us an opportunity to see all the park, as well as the end of day show.  The park is smaller than I expected, but good fun. Typical theme park prices inside ($12.99 for a hot dog, $5.99 for a small bottled drink...).  Loads to see and do at the park - and a recommended day out.  The show at the end of the day is worth hanging around for.

Thank you to the staff for making my bday so special... I was given a bday badge and was greated everywhere with a friendly happy birthday. Thank you to Norma in Kristy's burgers for showing us the mobile app food booking (life saver). And Kim in the monster cafe for making me feel so special on my bday, so friendly and helpful. Harry potter areas amazing, fast pass a must.. beets Disney hands down. The wand pairing was a lovely touch so happy I was chosen to partake. The night bus Conductor was funny as was Earl. Highly recommended.

Visiting in the second week of January, we were pleasantly surprised with generally short queue times and fantastic weather with which to visit the park. Being our second visit, we were able to target particular rides, and make the most of a single day visit. This place is really a wonderland, fantastic rides, good if expensive eating options, and I would definitely return. Great mix of rides suitable for all ages, and street shows such as Blues Brothers and Marilyn. Family favourite is still The Mummy. Would return for that. The cost is high, but as far as theme park goes, you get what you pay for, and you get a lot here.

Hi. Our experience in Hagrid’s Magical Creatures Motorbike Adventure today was the worst memory ever. We wait more tham 90 min, my kid RAFAELA BASTIAN was measured 3 times before our turn and all of them say “ok, have a great ride” for her. The last staff, before 90 min waiting, tell us that she isn’t tall enough! Why let her wait so long? Why others staffs tells that she can? Why they are so cruel with her? If the first guy told us that she is not tall enough we will lose our time in other part but they prefer lie to us until the time of the ride! Very sad pay a lot of money, spend a lot of time To see my Kid cry like that. You destroyed our magic Hogwarts memories today.
All the rides we went on were great. There weren’t a lot of people so we didn’t have lines but I would be frustrated at having to wait in a 2 hour line for a 30 second ride.

Last week I went with my friend (both of us in our 60's) to Universal Studios to see the Harry Potter parks. I do not like rides but she does. We spent 5 days (Monday-Friday) in the parks. We were hoping to avoid the crowds by going mid-week, and despite MLK Day on Monday, it wasn't bad. The weather Monday-Thursday was really cold and windy (Universal can't help the weather) but the weather meant that the rooftop bar at our hotel (Aventura) was closed, and several of the rides were closed on certain days during certain times.  Pros: Harry Potter World was so very well done. Although I don't like rides, several of the rides includes "shows" while you wait, so I waited with my friend as she walked through Gringotts and Hogwarts, which was awesome. For riders, they typically have a "single rider" option, so if you don't mind sitting by yourself, it's a lot quicker through the line as a single rider. Since we were there 5 days, we went to other areas (Suessland was visually stunning) and went to as many shows as we could. Employees were incredibly helpful, friendly and patient (they must get the same request for directions 1000 times but they are just as kind with everyone.) On Friday, the only warm day, I went to Volcano Bay and it was incredible. The water was warm and the beach was awesome.  The dragon in HP blows fire randomly throughout the day, and only on Thursday did we catch the fire-blowing, which takes about 3 seconds. There are also secret magic windows where you can use your wand (other windows have a marker on the ground in front of them.)  Cons: Food. Generally, the same extremely overpriced food (bad burgers and fries) is served throughout the parks and it's not good. At Harry Potter, you have to have butter beer ($8 for 16 ounces) (tastes like sweet butterscotch soda), but we went to breakfast at the Leaky Caldron (potatoes swimming in grease) and at the three Broomsticks (tasteless pasty). We found a good breakfast at the Today Cafe, and a good dinner at Grill and Brew in City Walk. Even snacks were ridiculous- $3 for a bag of chips. Universal can do a lot better. Side note- if you pay for your park ticket with your American Express card, you can use the AMEX lounge. It's a tiny room and there's not much there but it is air conditioned, a bathroom (single occupancy) has free chips and granola bars and small water bottles.  We went to the Horror Film Make-up show, which was generally pretty good. The presenters (a "funny" make up artist and a straight man) geared the show toward kids (plenty of fart jokes Hardy-har) but adults were entertained as well. However, and it's a big however, they made a racist joke (one audience volunteer was from Ecuador and the "funny" guy make a joke that we better not make her upset- she's from Ecuador and she'll "cut you".) and a completely inappropriate joke about women's biology ("Latex and Playtex are different- they create different monsters" Yuk yuk.) These are the kind of comments that, if made in front of my children, I would stand up against and let my children and the commenter know that these are disrespectful. Unfortunately, in the middle of the show no one was going to do that. I'm guessing that the Playtex joke went over the kids' heads, but I still felt disrespected and hope Universal will take notice and educate their presenters that these types of jokes are disrespectful, perpetuate a stereotype, and should be avoided.  Ride closures: We ran into one couple who were in for one day, They stood in line for Hagrid's ride for almost 2 hours, when the ride was shut down for technical difficulties. they were about 50 people from the front of the line. The announcement was that they weren't sure when the ride would reopen. There should be some method for accommodating people when the rides close and they have invested so much time waiting. Something like a "front of the line voucher" could be used.
Loved it here....better rides..not over crowded..less time waiting....better restaurants....keep it up guys....fantastic

I visited the park on a Monday. The wait times were amazing. I rode almost all the rides in the park. All the rides were so much fun, especially the 3D rides. There was something for all ages. The staff was very friendly. The 2pm parade was great. The different tv show characters came out around 4 pm. You could also take pictures with them. Some of the characters were Homer & Bart Simpson, Dora & Diego, Scooby & Shaggy, Marilyn Monroe and Betty Boop to name a few. It was great to see the kids and adults excited about seeing the characters. I had a blast and I can’t wait to go back.
Finally a park where teens can enjoy themselves too! My daughter had a great time much more energetic than Disney for older teens!
Everything is good!! VERY WELL ORGANIZED!! GO AND HAVE FUN!! It is much better than other disney parks.

We came out for our honeymoon and we really had a great time. We didn’t stay at a universal hotel but our own villa and went to all the parks. We spent most of our time at universal as we found it the best park. It’s well worth doing universal and islands of adventure because there’s a lot to take on at both. The theming in universal is better but the rides are better in islands of adventure. There’s only two good rollercoasters at universal mummy and rip ride rocket (the queue adverts need to be updated on this one as they are very annoying) Most of the rest is 4D which is ok but not my thing. Was disappointed that the only nod to Jaws was the statue I was kinda hoping in the closing fireworks display he might pop up. Still really good though
The best rides are the Mummy, Escape from Gringott's, and Rip Rocket. Most of the rides are simulators.

Just visited Universal Studios this past week. The weather in FL was very cold and windy. Most of the rides were closed due to the weather. Harry Potter experience was awesome for what we were able to do, 1 of the rides was closed for the 3 days we were there. We had arrived earlier than expected on Monday so we decided to go to the parks for a couple of hrs. On Thursday the weather was beautiful and all rides were open besides 1, so we went to the park stood in line over half hour for them to tell us that our passes expired. Due to the 3 day pass only. They counted Monday as a full day when we were there for 2 hrs. So upset with this. Recommend but pay close attention to what package you purchase when visiting the parks.

The photo package is not worth it! I ended up with less than 10 photos for my money! We rarely saw a photographer! The photos we got were taken on the rides. If the photographers were there, they did not stand out. I would never do this again. Total waste of money!

My husband and I visited Universal Studios Orlando last week. Not being riders of roller coasters or other motion sickness inducing experiences, we opted for a one day pass to the Universal Studios park, skipping Islands of Adventure and Harry Potter. First off, we were dismayed at the $26 daily parking fee. We feel a small fee is acceptable, but if guests are already paying a hefty entrance fee, price gouging on the parking is questionable. This was our first trip to Universal, and I had done some research before hand. Our favorite part was The Simpsons, which was cute and clever. We walked completely around City Walk, and ate lunch at the restaurant at the Simpsons. Lunch was fine, but we noticed the entire park was a little run down and dirty. Other than plenty of places to dine and buy souvenirs this park lacked anything much for us to do, since we didn’t ride any rides. One time will be enough for us.

As seniors we usually don't get too excted about rides especially roller coaster rides. However that said, the 3D rides of Transformers, Fast and Furious and The ride through New York with Jimmy Fallon open up a whole new adventure when it come to rides to thrill and amaze. It is without any doubt the first time that a ride makes you believe you could just reach out and touch. The Transformers ride is an absolute don't miss or you will regret your decision. It was pretty much the highlight of our entire outing.

In some ways, yes. The rides are more aggressive than most of what Disney offers, and the lines move faster. Of course you can also purchase a pass to bypass the lines, too. The best way to see all of the biggest attractions in one day is to purchase a guided tour.

I’m not really into theme parks anymore, but I had fun with my family at Universal. I was very impressed by the number of restrooms, as well as the cleanliness of the entire park. The rides were fun and innovative. We also went to the Horror Makeup show, which was really funny. Be prepared for long lines and lots of people . As long as you go in expecting some chaos, you’ll enjoy yourself.

For us this was better than Disney. There feels more to do here and at the time we traveled it was easier to get onto rides. We did both parks in one day relatively easy. Our son practically went on all the rides (we did get him a express pass). But our time at both Universal and Disney here in Florida and again in Los Angeles, Universal seemed easier to get onto rides (fast) and Disney is just very packed. Anyway - highly recommend Universal - great options for food - big range to choose from.

We spent five days in October with family at Disney World Orlando staying at the Pop Century Resort and three days two nights in January at Universal Orlando staying at the Hard Rock Hotel (club level). Both were quite expensive and you really need deep pockets for sure but Universal came out on top in our opinion. Disney's rides were more varied but we enjoyed the Hogwart Express and various Harry Potter attractions more. The simulator rides at Universal were very similar to one another, but the Simpsons ride was the best. The water taxi which takes you to City Walk near Universal and Island of Adventure was very nice, and you can easily walk from Hard Rock Hotel to either park. Contrast that with Disney which has a bus system which requires you to walk forever before you even get into the park. Hard Rock has a restaurant, the Kitchen, at the hotel which is terrific while Disney's Pop Century has the most awful cafeteria food and no real restaurant. All the restaurants we tried at Universal and City Walk were nice with good food...we stayed at the Club level, 7th floor, at Hard Rock and that is the way to go if you can afford the rates...amenities like breakfast, snacks, evening beverages were really nice and you never had to leave your floor of the hotel at the end of a long day at the parks. You also get the Express Pass when you stay at Hard Rock which lets you skip the lines. We never waited for any rides at Universal, but it is also a slower time of year. Overall Universal would be our choice to do again. Also, other reviews mentioned workers who did not seem to care...we did not find that to be the case at all. Everyone at Hard Rock, Universal Studios and Island of Adventure was welcoming and helpful.

First ever visit at an age of 60+. So much to see. We only had one day in the area so opted for one park ticket which was expensive but you only live once. Enjoyed walking round and seeing the fascinating buildings. We went on many of the rides and although we had to queue did not seem to mind as so much going on around you. Enjoyed Harry Potter, but have to the studios in England and did prefer that. Again there was so much to see and had a butter beer. The only ride we did not enjoy was The Mummy because we did not realise it was a rollercoaster and was very fast, great if you like that sort of thing. Loved the Monster make up show, very funny and interesting learning the tricks of the make up artist. All in all a great day out and was walking distance from our hotel The Wyndham.

Already reviewed the other park. This one was a little better. This park has much wider streets and walkways compared to Islands of Adventures so you don’t quite feel like cattle being herded to your death. The rides are fun but only the really big thrill rides last a minute or more. Otherwise you wait in line 45 minutes for your kids to ride something for 20 seconds, that’s literal. We are pass holders at Disney so I know how expensive theme parks are. No outside food or drinks are allowed, so that $5 bottle is a necessity plus the food is more expensive too, if you can even stand in line long enough to get “quick service food”. But with a food allergy, I was annoyed that I couldn’t bring my own snacks in. It’s not like I didn’t spend over $1500 for two days of park time for my whole family, plus all the souvenirs. The restrooms were not clean, there was trash on the ground and I’m not used to that. Overall it was a huge disappointment and it will be 10 years before I’m willing to do it again to take our youngest child that was too small to go this time.

I was lucky enough to spend 2 1/2 days at Universal. I was stunned at how expensive the tickets were but thanks to my amazement and enjoyment of the two Harry Potter sections of the park (and I'm not even a huge fan) I'd have to say it was $ well spent. I'd recommend a half-day all park ticket if you can visit during the week but NOT on a holiday or school break time. If you have a whole day to spend and are more than a party of two, be there when the park opens and go for the express upgrade. You can easily do all three park sections very well with express and an entire day. Enjoy!

Okay, if you have kids that just have to see the Harry Potter theme parks (half in Universal Studios and half in Universal Adventure Land - so you have to buy a 2-park pass), then I guess you have to bit the bullet. But for me, it was WAY overpriced for the value of entertainment. I wanted to ride the Hogwarts coaster, but was not prepared to wait 90 min - and that was in off season! Overpriced merchandise everywhere. $50 for a wand? I wanted to mail ONE post card. I would have had to buy a package of cards and a package of stamps - $30. Jimmy Fallon's Race Through New York was a blast. But, if I could do it all over again, - I wouldn't.
Fun as always. This was the first time using the express pass to cut the line. We will never go back to waiting more than 20 minutes for a ride.

We love Universal Studios and Islands of adventure over Disney but we will not return to Universal Studios and Islands of Adventure. The family is going to be in Orlando for an upcoming weekend and have a day or two free. We looked at the costs of a 1 day ticket for Universal Studios and Islands of Adventure vs Disney park hoppers. It’s February so the water parks are off the agenda. We visited both parks last summer so we know what there is in both Universal and Disney. We counted the rides we were able to get on in our average one day vs ticket costs for each park. We did not add in any taxes, food, drink, parking or souvenir costs. Universal Studios and Islands of adventure worked out to around 30.00 a ride. Disney worked out to around 12.00 a ride. Both are very expensive but clearly Disney wins out and has more places to visit and see for less money. We were going/wanted to go to Universal and Islands of Adventure but this changes our minds completely. Guess who is now paying for all the overbuilt Harry Potter rides? Having rode them this summer I can say they or any ride there is just not worth 30 bucks a ride. I am sure the prices “improve” if you stay longer but do they? Longer stays result in more money spent with less to do then in the bigger Disney. So it’s really not a deal. I am not a huge fan of Disney either, so please don’t think I am. It’s just dollars and sense. Hey go to each place, have loads of fun and then afterwards do your own cost analysis. WHOEVER the looser is, dump them off your next trip to Orlando, sending them a clear message!

There are 2 parks at Universal plus a water park. We skipped the water park (Volcano Bay) and went to Islands of Adventure and Universal (original). This was our second visit in three years. Universal, the original is more for those who want the "movie" experience. They have mostly 3D "rides" and the Harry Potter Escape from Gringotts (used to be located in the other park). The Hogwarts Express also runs through the park (but you have to have a 2 park ticket to ride the train). Be forewarned! On this side of the park, go early!! It's not as popular as the other park and even though we were there during the Christmas holidays, it was almost empty at 9:00 in the morning. But it gets really crowded later with minimum wait times of 100 minutes or longer. Fast passes probably would be helpful here, but we didn't want to pay the extra $70 - 90 p.p. We ended up going on many of the rides in this park. I think this is down to the (old-fashioned) rides not being able to accommodate the sheer volume of visitors at a brisk pace like the rides in the other park. Diagon Ally is incredibly crowded. They've done a superior job in replicating the town center, unfortunately, that kind of layout doesn't bode well for a mob of enthusiasts. On the bright side, the Gringotts ride was worth the 90 minute wait. We went there first thing, later it was a 205 minute wait! The food at the Leaky Cauldron was really good. The Islands of Adventure is geared towards the thrill seekers. Great rides and short(er) wait times. Hagrids motorbike ride is by far the best themed ride in the park. Buyer beware, as you might guess, gift shop prices are ridiculously expensive. It was a fun, but exhausting 2 days.

Spent 5 days in the 2 parks. Universal was great, the Gringotts ride was fun and the Dragon worth seeing but you have to catch it quick as it's over in seconds! Weather was good and mid week queues not too long. Bank Holiday weekend was predictably busy. Definitely fun for all the family even if you don't like the big rollercoasters. The Hogwarts Express is a great way to travel between parks. Looking forward to the next visit 😁

Visited both Universal and Islands of Adventure in Jan with my two teenage sons. Although we only had one day we did a lot (most of the coasters) and enjoyed it. As overseas visitors it was quite expensive, but we all enjoyed it more than any of the Disney parks. Much better suited to teenagers.

We had a blast at Universal! We felt like kids again running through the park. Our favorite ride was Hagrid’s motorcycle ride in the Harry Potter section, which we rode twice. I would have paid for a ticket to visit Hogsmeade alone. So much fun! The only downsides were the crowds and the long wait times. Some of the rides closed their single rider line as well.

This was my favourite park of the holiday in the end but only because of being able to get into Harry Potter & other rides without an insane wait. At times, it was 90mins or longer for the popular rides but towards the start & end of the day's it was more like 20-40 mins waiting. If you can afford the express pass its worth it. Didn't manage to get on Hagrids Motorbike ride & this one isn't an express pass option but the other HP rides were amazing. Good to have free small lockers at relevant rides. Can take food in but not in a cooler. Can be a long walk from car to parks. Hogwarts train goes between the two & is well worth trying 8n both directions if the wait is not too bad. Note that Diagon Alley is hidden behind a wall, look for people wandering into it near the tube station. Huge crowds at all HP bits of the two parks. Tip: buy any two matinee tickets (between 11 & 6) on your way into the parks & get a refund on parking which makes it much cheaper ($15.98 instead of 26) & you can either go or not, we did see the film so effectively parked for free.

We stayed in Orlando & visited the studios & Islands of Adventure every day for 6 days. We had an amazing time, the staff were friendly & helpful, the interaction with the characters was incredible & only down side was very long queue's on some days but all in all it was better than expected plus we got to see the Macy's Christmas parade which was brilliant.

Arrived to Universal at approx 8:40am. Purchased tickets online in advance on arrival we had to wait in an extremely long line at will call to pick up tickets, Then again was directed to guest services to wait in an additional line to obtain a Disability Pass for my husband who suffers from severe PTSD from the Military and son who suffers from ADHD and ODD disorders. It was now approx 10:30am and we are just entering the park. Upon entering the park we walked through Dr Seuss area and were excited for the Harry Potter Area. The Harry Potter area seemed to be way over capacity and so crowded that you could not walk without someone running in to you let alone push my toddler in a stroller. After someone pushed into our stroller We tried to enter several stores/restaurants in this area to get out of the crowds and did not even have enough room to enter or push a stroller in. Several student groups were laying on the ground with book bags piled up and crowds trying to walk around them...this should not be allowed. We wanted to ride the Hagrid's Bike ride and using my husbands disability pass. We had a return time of 45 minutes so we sat and waited behind a close by store as my husband at this point was ready to leave due to all the chaos and his PTSD. It was time for us to enter the express line and we were in line for an additional 35 minutes setting in a tight dark cave packed with people clapping and screaming. My husband was ready to loose his mind as he was sitting on the floor with is head down. An announcement was then made the ride was closed due to technical difficulties and was not sure when it would reopen and we followed the crowd and found an exit. At this point my husband needed to get out of the Harry Potter area. We then went to ride the Jurassic Park Area and upon entering most of the Jurassic park section was blocked off for construction with high temporary walls and the Jurassic Park ride was closed. My son wanted to meet Blue...not surprised it was also down for technical issues for the rest of the day! At this point it is almost 1:30pm and we have done absolutely NOTHING but fight crowds and wait in lines to not ride anything. At this point my kids were crying and my husband was very upset so we started to walk out of the park. On our way our We did stop at Blondie's: Home of the Dagwood for lunch as we would not arrive back to our hotel for 45 minutes. I waited to get a table while my husband waited in line to order food. No one was wiping down the tables so I did using baby wipes. I had the Dagwood Sandwich only which was good, my husband and kids had the foot long hot dogs(small cold and stale bread) and my husband had a beer. Our total was $57.67! I expected high food prices but not for hot dogs that were awful! We finished walking out and decided to let our daughter ride a few rides back at the Dr Seuss area first. We went to the One Fish, Two Fish ride and got in line waited 20 minutes and surprise, the ride closed for technical difficulties!! My husband could not wait in another line at customer serve on our way out to talk to someone about our concerns. We both feel like we paid ALOT of money for tickets and also an Uber ride to and from All Star Sports resort Area.

Your trip would not be complete without this park. I personally liked it better than the Island of Adventure, which really surprised me. It has everything from rides to shows to great eats. There is a lot to take in so be prepared to spend more than one day to fully enjoy it. If visiting at peak season, splurge on the express pass for at least one day of your trip to skip the long lines you've been avoiding. I also suggest a park hopper for at least one day. It's nice to have the option to wander or take the Hogwarts Express to Island of Adventure. We utilized this more at the end of our trip to hit the rides here and there we missed.

Late December and lots of people but still well worth the visit. We had an exclusive pass that allowed us on ALL rides in BOTH parks so that was a blessing. I am a Central Florida resident and know when to go and when not to, if we didn't have a freind in upper management who got us in all rides from the back employee entrance, would have never gone. The roller coasters are fantastic and the Mummy is my fan favorite from the movie. Best of all, Hagrid's ride is absolutely the best.
Loved loved loved it! Our kids loved it and even our little ones. They were so entertained which made for a well behaved day as well. They had a blast!

I like Universal Studios, it’s kept a happy balance of original with a healthy mix of modern and up-to date.  Ride wait times were not bad at all and during our visit managed to easily get on all the rides and the main roller coaster 3 times in quick succession.  There are plenty of pop up performances throughout the day too to break it up for you if you want entertainment whilst you stop for a while.  Food quality isn’t that great for the price and the portion sizes could use a little work.  The only real gripe Is with some of the rides themselves. There is a very similar theme throughout the majority of them along the lines of ‘escape from something’ or other. It’s mainly on the 4D rides which are ok, but the majority of the Universal Studios rides are now all of the. Same concept, something of personal preference I don’t enjoy as much as more traditional hands on full movement experiences.

I’m sharing a recent visit to Universal Orlando park where my family and I did the VIP tour. Thursday, December 5th, we arrived at the park approximately an hour early to check in and enjoy the breakfast. Both the breakfast and lunch were fantastic. Zac showed up and introduced himself as our tour guide before leading my family and one other on our tour.  We enjoyed the information given by Zac as we got to our first ride; however, we didn’t see anything that we wouldn’t have seen if we were a regular guest at the park. We quickly learned to stand a few feet from Zac as he tends to spit when he talks. That’s not meant as an insult, but people paying good money for a tour don’t want to be spit on all day. Between rides, he moved very slowly. The park was not crowded, most waits for rides were under 15 minutes, and we felt we lost time enjoying the park due to the slow transition from attraction to attraction, especially when he was on his cell phone (which was often). By 1130, the other family in our group decided to leave the tour and venture on their own. I don’t know their reason for this, but looking back on the day, we definitely could have experienced more of the park had we done the same.  After the other family left, I told Zac our main focus was riding rides, and we wanted to visit the prop room. We didn’t care as much for information, we specifically bought the VIP expecting a larger crowd at the park, and thus purchased it for the unlimited express pass and front of the line ability. Zac stated he understood and could get us through the 14 rides he was allowed to take us on and be done by 1430. We went to lunch shortly after this. Once he returned, I expected the pace to pick up. It did not. Between every ride my kids and I would be out in front of him. We would have to turn around, stop, and wait for him to tell us which way we were going. At the two large coasters, The Hulk and The Red Rocket, he belittled two of my children for being scared to go on those rides. Even I wouldn’t go on them, only my wife and one child would. My wife was infuriated by his comments but kept it to herself. Despite Zac stating we’d be done by 1430, and could then use our express passes to get through the rest of the rides, our tour didn’t finish until 1615, and we were never taken to the prop room.  Overall, my family and I LOVE Universal studios. It’s our favorite park in Orlando, and that is why we purchased the VIP experience for the park. Unfortunelty, we were extremely disappointed in our VIP experience. I read tons of reviews from people who did the VIP and loved it and their tour guide. People stated their guides took pictures of the their family, provided waters and ponchos. We had to ask for a poncho on the Jurassic Park River Adventure. He commented to the store worker, “their making me get them rain ponchos.” His tone made my wife feel guilty for asking for one. He never once offered to take a picture of our family or offered us water. After the park closed and we finished shopping at the stores, we attempted to go by the VIP office to discuss our visit, but they were already closed. Once, we returned home, we wrote the above review and emailed it to them. We got a preworded standard response that our experience would be forwarded to people higher up, and we'd be contacted. We never were. My wife called them 2 weeks later and was told someone would call her back. Again no response.
Lines were very long but rides never disappoint. Staff is amazing as always, but souvenirs are a bit expensive.

Got there early and rode several of the more popular rides without a wait. Layer waits of 20-30 minutes were average during a mid January weekday. Park was clean and shows with animals and make-up were more entertaining than the rides which all seemed similar with 3 D glasses and fast faux motion with chairs that changed direction with the scenery. Food was expensive, so be sure to bring a back pack with snacks and water bottles.
There is something for everyone. The rides are amazing! More rides than island of adventure. Jimmy Fallon 3D is great. The mummy is one of our favorite and transformers. I highly recommend this park!

AMAZING! Had Douglas as a guide and he was incredible. He knew so much about the park and was very attentive to our needs. Great ambassador for Universal. Had enough time to do two parks in one day and not feel rushed. Universal Studios and Islands of Adventure were amazing. Loved Hagrid's Motorbike ride. Great time of year to go not super crowded. Was our first visit and we all had a blast!
We felt like we had stepped into that galaxy far far away. We were totally blown away with the detail that Disney had taken to make you feel like you were in Star Wars.

We have been here probably 10 times in the past 2 years and we love the place.  Always clean and the staff are hard working and friendly.  It has some fabulois rides...Harry Potter, The Mummy, Simpsons, Jimmy Fallon etc and some good shops.  I love coming here of a night as its cooler and the ambience is more relaxed, plus the queue times are often a lot smaller.  Love this place...its like a second home to me and my partner.
If in Orlando visiting Disney World, be sure to spend some time at Universal. The park has something for everybody. We were so impressed with the attractions! Will definitely go back!

Any amount of time spent there is not enough. We did the Gringotts ride, MIB, Transformers, Mummy, Fast and Furious rides. The line ups were really long with Gringotts being 120 minutes. Be prepared to spend a lot of time in line ups with no food and water and bathroom break. The new thing from our last trip was that you had to check in your bags/ back packs. Carry standard size bags as the over sized ones don't fit in the lockers. It is USD 2 per locker. Smaller lockers are free. We could wait in the child swap section with the oversized backpack and swap for the rides. They could do with some more staff inside some rides as the line ups are snaky and winding and dark. Not ideal for claustrophobic people.Also some electronic signs to say how far into the time are you at that spot would also help.

If you like motion simulators this is the place for you. The Harry potter rides were the only thing I would ride more then once. I like real amusement rides, where the drops and spins are real. The coaster here was broken for most of the day I was there. They kept working on it, testing it, then opening the line, only to have it break down again, after 5 hours I was done with the place, and we had the park hopper where we could go back and forth...It is just too expensive and not enough diversity. I will never go back

We split our visit between a Saturday and a Monday. On Saturday, Lyft dropped us off and we entered Universal Studios and went directly to Diagon Alley. It was crowded, but very fun. We rode Escape from Gringotts, exchanged money and rode the train to Hogwarts.The train was great! We skipped Hogwarts (visited Monday - see magical moment review) and went on everything we wanted. We enjoyed all attractions, with the exception of The Mummy. There are other areas that have space to just breath, rest and explore. Waits were minimal for attractions. We sat by the water at Duff's Brewery and then walked over to Moe's to just check it out. Over all a great day and we left before closing and returned on Monday.

Visited two nights for HHN29. First time visiting and have booked for HHN30. The place is amazing. Scareactors are professional. Houses are so good, especially Us. Stranger Things was amazing, we walked through at the perfect time! Can’t wait to come back!

On Jan 15, visited the park with my family from Toronto.  It was kind of a unique experience with some of the simulation rides such as Harry Potter. Express entry pass helped us get easy access to most of the rides. I personally think it can be very tough for families with young kids to stand in such long line up in a cramped environment with not much shade around: so, better to get an easy access pass, when possible. Most of the rides required, locker service to keep your belongings prior to departure; therefore, it's better not to carry large back packs as they may not even fit in the locker( also costs you $3 for locker rental).  The chief issue with this place is the lack of enthusiasm in employees ( with few exceptions); most of them walked like a zombie and showed no interest in "serving with a smile" Among them, the worst of all were-Renatta and Dani(greeters at Harry Potter ride). When approached them to inquire about the wait time, replied mockingly "read the board,says 120 mts" When we replied with the feed back that a proper customer service also means a caring attitude, her friend Dani walked in to defend her and replied-- " you got the information,now out" They also shouted from behind, make sure you complaint at the guest service on your way out and had good laugh between them.Renata, also reminded not to forget that her name spells with 2Ts!! What an unprofessional team !!  My recommendation is-this is not a place for everyone. If you like simulation rides so much, willing to wait in long line up in a cramped place under the sun ( not many trees around), ready to put up with unfriendly staff, and able to pay $273 (including express pass), go for it!!  foot note: we had spent 4 happy days at Disneyworld prior to going to universal--I think, it was the friendly staff who made the experience more memorable at Disney)..

We did a one day off season visit. We only did one day as our focus was Harry Potter and we wanted our overall trip to be low key.  We did the park hopper which is surprisingly expensive compared to the park to park. However, it is needed for one day and I would recommend for multiple.  It was not crowded at all (Wednesday) and we arrived when the park opened. The only ride with a long line was the new Hagrid ride. All others had little to no waits. We easily did both Harry Potter parks in half a day and spent the rest in the other areas. Seeing everything would require two days.  We ate at the Leaky Cauldron which was cute. Food was very expensive.  The light show on the castle was the perfect end to the trip.  My biggest complaint was that the park closed at 7 PM. Way too early and limited what we were able to see.

This review is about park value...did we get the bang for our buck and could we have done better?  After finding $80 flights we set a budget of $1800 for four from Chicago - we were willing to spend more but not if we didn't have to.  The two parks (Studios and Islands) are right next to each other and connect (about 400 meters apart) via the front gates or via the Hogwarts Express on the backside. We never considered the water park as we have showers at home.  With tax we spent just under $1100 on park tickets and got four park to park tickets for three days. We stayed at a Universal hotel and got into the Universal Studios park an hour early. Here are some tips:  1. Park to Park. I would make this a priority. The Hogwarts Express was excellent but we also switched parks from the front a couple of times. You can definitely get tired of the Universal Studio rides in under a day and you could eliminate a wasted "rain day" on the Island side by having the indoor rides on the Studios side.
